titleproper.value: Guide to the New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH) Records <num>WAG.029</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-04-08T14:39:22</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH) Records

extent.value: in 61 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, and 1 oversize flat box

abstract.value: The New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH) was founded in 1976 to advocate for safe and healthy workplaces. NYCOSH bases much of its advocacy on the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 and has helped spearhead successful efforts to preserve the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). The collection includes minutes of membership, steering committee, health and technical committee, personnel committee, political education committee and workers' compensation committee meetings, general correspondence, requests for assistance, membership records, course materials, publicity flyers, fact sheets, newsletters, fund raising materials, pamphlets, lobbying materials, and educational materials.

p.value: Identification of item, date; New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH) Records; WAG 029; Box number; Folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Board Minutes from 2012 - 2013 donated by the NYCOSH, 2016. The accession number associated with this gift is 2016.006

Recently, NYCOSH has been involved in the struggle to gain medical screening and care for 9/11's first responders and cleanup workers. NYCOSH's longtime Executive Director, Joel Shufro, retired in 2014.

The other documents constituting the bulk of this collection are correspondence. The correspondence includes lobbying material sent to political figures, form letters regarding dues payment, invitations, notification of conferences, networking letters to other COSH groups, unions, and political groups, and basic requests for information regarding health and safety issues and NYCOSH itself. VDT hazards, right to know material and workers' compensation materials, although less in bulk, are important aspects of the collection. These materials include legislation drawn up under the auspices of NYCOSH to strengthen workers' compensation in New York State and VDT guidelines in New York City. NYCOSH sponsored two "right to know" conferences and was active in lobbying for stricter legislation regarding employers' responsibility to inform workers and near by residents of the presence of toxic materials.

Series I: Management5437911977-1989Scope and Content Note

Series I: Management, 1977-1989 includes the minutes of all NYCOSH committees, correspondence, technical inquiries, fund raising material, financial information, membership files, information regarding other COSH groups, nationally and internationally, and the New York State COSH.

Series II: Activities, 1979-1987 contains the material relating to major NYCOSH activities. The activities series is divided into three subseries, the Committee to Save OSHA, NYCOSH conferences, and general health and safety activities and information. The first subseries is self-explanatory, the second includes that material associated with NYCOSH sponsored conferences and includes all research material associated with the topics of asbestos, office hazards, VDTs, and the Harlem Occupational Health Conference. The final subseries, general health and safety activities and information, contains workers' compensation and "right to know" resources, research material for a variety of occupational diseases and hazards, scholarly health and safety articles, health and safety newsletters, and general labor information and activities. The activities series is organized by activity and where possible by chronology.

The unprocessed materials in this collection relate to various health and safety campaigns. General information and research on these issues is also included. Major health and workers' issues documented include asbestos, needlestick injuries, workers' compensation, VDTs, and reproductive health. Professions represented in this series include teachers, transportation workers, government employees, health care employees, and others. NYCOSH's advocacy and general information on these issues are documented through correspondence, reports, fliers, pamphlets, posters, newsletters, government documents, news clippings, conference materials, financial records, and other materials.

Box 60cuid8008544999circa 1980-201160Scope and Content Note

This box contains materials from NYCOSH retreats and assorted news articles, speeches, and correspondence, likely collected by Joel Shufro.

Box 61cuid80095449971989-200361Scope and Content Note

This box contains campaign files related to NYCOSH's advocacy on the issues of workers' compensation, needlestick injuries (as a member of the Needlestick Injury Prevention Coalition), and medical monitoring. Other campaign files pertain to opposition to various OSHA reform bills that proposed to weaken the agency's enforcement powers, the "reinvention" of OSHA in 1995, and the New York State Occupational Safety and Health Training and Education program.

The box also includes subject files on Presidents Bush and Clinton's relationships to OSHA, specific members of congress, members of affiliated organizations, Workers Memorial Days, asbestos, the Cornell/NYCOSH Occupational Safety and Health Certificate Program, and other topics. There are a few files containing citations and complaints against the Public Employee Safety and Health program (PESH) of the New York State Department of Labor, New York State United Teachers' applications to the New York state Occupational Safety and Health Training grant, and a small amount of NYCOSH office administration material.

Ingoing and Outgoing Correspondencecuid80105450002003-201162Box 63cuid80115450641981-201163Scope and Content Note

This box contains a mockup of a poster for the NYCOSH-sponsored Right to Know Conference in 1981, a poster for the centennial commemoration of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire, and three poster advertisements regarding workers' compensation for 9/11 responders (one in Spanish). There are also several federal, state, and local government proclamations recognizing Workers Memorial Days and Teen Worker Safety Month, as well as a "VDT Safety Now!" button and an informational booklet created by the New York State Public Employees Federation, AFL-CIO on Public Employees Safety and Health (PESH)Act/OSHA standards.

Series IV: Archived Websitecuid8012547021Apr 16, 2009-ongoing

New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health

Scope and Content Note

New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH), founded in 1980, is a non-profit coalition of 200 local unions and more than 400 individual workers, physicians, lawyers and other health and safety activists dedicated to the right of worker safety on the job. NYCOSH operates throughout New York City, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley. The website gives information and assistance for those injured on the job and other training and safety resources.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
